alert.note: Alert for Lewis (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 01 at 9:16AM PST until March 02 at 8:26AM PST by NWS Seattle
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Washington... Deschutes River Near Rainier affecting Thurston County. ...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Washington... Nisqually River Near National affecting Lewis and Pierce Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Washington... White River At R Street Bridge affecting King and Pierce Counties. Cowlitz River At Randle affecting Lewis County. Puyallup River Near Orting affecting Pierce County. .Heavy rain has ended and remaining showers will diminish today, allowing the some rivers to recede. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Cowlitz River At Randle. * WHEN...Until tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, the Cowlitz River will cause minor flooding from the vicinity of Randle downstream through Riffe Lake...covering nearby farm lands and several roads. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 19.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:00 AM PST Tuesday was 19.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 19.3 feet late this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.0 feet on 11/11/1995. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued by this morning at 1015 AM PST.
